Boost Your Immunity This Fall: Why Gut Health Is the Secret to Staying Well

The back-to-school season has a way of sneaking up on us. One minute it’s late-summer barbecues, and
the next, we’re stocking up on hand sanitizer and tissues. As schedules get busier, kids (and
adults) are spending more time indoors, and as the air gets cooler, we officially enter what many
call “sick season.” Fall and winter naturally bring more exposure to germs, less sunshine (hello,
lower vitamin D), and more stress on routines. Supporting your immune system *before* illness hits
makes all the difference — it’s easier to prevent than to play catch-up.

This is the time of year when your immune system deserves some extra love. And the best place to
start? Your gut.

## Gut Health and Immunity: The Connection You Can’t Ignore

About 70% of your immune system lives in your gut. That means the trillions of microbes in your
digestive tract are not just busy helping you digest food — they’re training your immune cells,
calming unnecessary inflammation, and helping your body know when it’s time to fight off invaders.

When your gut health is strong, your immune system is more balanced. When it’s struggling, you may
be more prone to illness, fatigue, or even those “I just can’t shake this” lingering bugs.

## Immune-Boosting Foods

Building a resilient immune system doesn’t have to be complicated. It’s about making consistent
choices that nourish your gut and keep your body ready to respond when an invader strikes. Here are
some easy ways to get started:

### 1. Eat the Rainbow (and Load Up on Fiber)

Fiber is your gut bacteria’s favorite food! When you feed them well, they produce short-chain fatty
acids (SCFAs) that calm inflammation and strengthen your gut lining. The more variety you eat, the
stronger and more diverse your microbiome becomes.

**Ideas to try:**

- Add spinach or kale and a tablespoon of chia seeds to morning smoothies.
- Roast a tray of colorful veggies (carrots, bell peppers, zucchini, beets) and keep them in the
fridge for easy add-ins or a quick side dish.
- Choose whole grains like quinoa, brown rice, or whole rolled oats for extra fiber.
- Snack on apples, pears, or berries with nut butter for a combo of fiber and healthy fats

### 2. Add Fermented Foods

Fermented foods naturally contain probiotics, which can support a healthier balance of gut bacteria.
Regular intake has been linked to better immune responses and fewer respiratory infections.

**Ideas to try:**

- Sauerkraut or kimchi as a side dish, salad topper, or even in tacos or on top of your morning eggs.
- Kefir or unsweetened yogurt (look for “live active cultures” on the label). If you’re dairy-free,
try almond, cashew, oat, or coconut yogurts with added probiotics.
- Miso paste in soups, sauces or marinades.
- Tempeh which is a protein-rich, fermented soy option works well in stir-fries.
- If fermented foods aren’t your thing, a quality probiotic supplement can help fill the gap.

### 3. Choose Healthy Fats

Healthy fats help your body absorb fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), all of which are key for
immunity. They also support the structure of your cell membranes — your body’s first line of
defense.

**Ideas to try:**

- Drizzle olive oil over roasted vegetables.
- Smash avocado onto gluten-free toast or add to salads. Hint: avocado is also a great source of
fiber.
- Snack on a small handful of walnuts, almonds, or pumpkin seeds.
- Use chia or flaxseeds in overnight oats or smoothies for an omega-3 boost.
- Fatty fish like salmon, sardines, or anchovies are rich in omega-3’s. For those avoiding fish,
consider adding an omega-3 supplement.

### 4. Prioritize Protein

Your immune system can’t build infection-fighting cells and antibodies without adequate protein.
Spreading protein throughout the day (rather than just at dinner) helps your body use it more
efficiently.

**Ideas to try:**

- Grilled chicken, turkey, or lean beef added to grain bowls or soups.
- Lentils, chickpeas, or black beans in salads, stews, or wraps.
- Plant or whey-based protein powders in smoothies.
- Hard-boiled eggs or edamame as quick snacks.
- Collagen peptides added to coffee or tea for an easy protein boost.

### 5. Stay Hydrated

Hydration keeps mucous membranes in your nose, throat, and lungs moist — and those membranes are
your immune system’s “sticky traps” for germs. Even mild dehydration can weaken this defense.

**Ideas to try:**

- Aim for half your body weight in ounces of water daily.
- Add lemon, cucumber, or berries to water if plain water feels boring.
- Warm herbal teas like ginger, chamomile, or peppermint can be soothing *and* hydrating.
- Include water-rich foods like cucumbers, citrus, and melons.

### 6. Support With Supplements

or stressful seasons. Certain nutrients have been consistently shown to support immunity and gut
health. And when illness does strike? Having the right tools on hand — from probiotics to zinc
lozenges — can help shorten the duration and get you back to feeling yourself again, sooner.

Let’s be honest — carbs get blamed for just about everything these days. Tired? Must be carbs.
Bloated? Carbs. Didn’t get that promotion? Probably the carbs.

But here’s the truth: your body *loves* carbohydrates and for good reason. They’re your main energy
source and play a key role in brain power, digestion, hormone balance, and mood. Let’s dig into what
they really are, why you need them, and how to choose the ones that make you feel good (and yes,
still enjoy a cookie sometimes)!

## What Are Carbohydrates?

Carbohydrates (or “carbs”) are one of the three main macronutrients — alongside protein and fat.
When you eat them, your body breaks them down into glucose, which becomes your go-to energy source.

Think of carbs as premium fuel for your body’s engine — they keep your brain sharp, your muscles
moving, and your mood steady. In fact, your brain alone uses about 20% of your daily energy intake
in glucose.

## Common Myths About Carbs

Let’s clear the air — carbs don’t deserve their bad reputation. It’s time to give them the credit
they deserve!

**Myth #1: “Carbs make you gain weight.”******Nope. Overeating anything can lead to weight gain, but
balanced carbs — especially fiber-rich ones — actually help regulate appetite and support a healthy
metabolism.

**Myth #2: “You don’t need carbs.”******Wrong again. Your body needs carbohydrates for energy,
digestion, and hormone balance. Even if you follow a very low-carbohydrate or ketogenic diet, your
body still produces glucose because it’s essential for energy, digestion, and hormone balance.

**Myth #3: “All carbs are the same.”******False. White bread is not the same as sweet potatoes. The
type of carb matters — complex, whole-food carbs provide fiber, vitamins, and minerals, while
refined carbs tend to spike blood sugar and leave you feeling sluggish.

## Why Our Bodies Need Carbs

Carbs aren’t just about energy — they’re multitaskers:

- **Brain Power:** Glucose fuels focus, memory, and mood.
- **Physical Energy:** Muscles depend on carbs during movement and exercise.
- **Fullness and Craving Control:** Fiber-rich carbs help you feel satisfied and reduce sugar
cravings.
- **Digestive and Gut Health:** Complex carbs feed beneficial gut bacteria.
- **Blood Sugar Balance:** Slow-digesting carbs prevent the dreaded afternoon crash.
- **Hormone Support:** Adequate carbs help balance cortisol and support thyroid health.

Your body truly thrives on quality carbs — the kind that come with fiber, vitamins, and color!

## Types of Carbohydrates –

Here’s a quick guide to the types of carbs and where to find them:

### Whole Grains

**Examples:** Quinoa, brown rice, oats, millet, barley, farro**Why they’re great:** High in fiber, B
vitamins, magnesium, and protein**How to enjoy:** Warm grain bowls, overnight oats, or alongside
roasted veggies

### Root and Starchy Vegetables

**Examples:** Sweet potatoes, carrots, beets, peas, squash**Why they’re great:** Rich in fiber,
antioxidants, and slow-digesting carbs**How to enjoy:** Roasted, mashed, or tossed into soups and
salads

### Fruits

**Examples:** Berries, apples, pears, bananas, mango**Why they’re great:** Natural sugars plus fiber
and vitamins like C and potassium**How to enjoy:** Fresh, frozen, or paired with protein like nuts
or yogurt

### Legumes

**Examples:** Lentils, chickpeas, black beans, kidney beans**Why they’re great:** A combination of
carbs, fiber, and plant protein**How to enjoy:** In soups, stews, salads, or pureed into hummus

### Non-Starchy Vegetables

**Examples:** Broccoli, cauliflower, leafy greens, peppers, zucchini**Why they’re great:** Low in
carbs but high in nutrients and antioxidants**How to enjoy:** Raw, roasted, sautéed, or blended into
smoothies

## How to Incorporate the Right Carbs

- Pair carbs with protein and healthy fat to slow digestion and balance blood sugar.
- Make them colorful — aim for a rainbow of fruits and vegetables.
- Stay mindful, not fearful. Cravings for sweets can sometimes be your body’s way of signaling low
energy or unmet nutritional needs. Choose balanced, nourishing foods first — and if you still want
something sweet, enjoy it without guilt and move on.

## Final Thoughts

Carbs aren’t the enemy — they’re essential. The key is quality over quantity. When you focus on
whole, fiber-rich carbohydrates from foods like fruits, vegetables, legumes, and whole grains,
you’re giving your body the kind of steady energy it was designed to use.

Carbohydrates support your mood, digestion, hormones, and brain health. The right carbs help you
stay focused, calm, and satisfied throughout the day.

So the next time someone tells you to “cut the carbs,” smile and pass them the sweet potatoes.
Fueling your body smarter means nourishing it deeper and choosing what truly serves you well.

Is Your Gut Asking for a Reset? 10 Signs You Shouldn’t Ignore

When most people think about gut health, they picture digestion—whether food sits well, whether they
feel bloated, or how often they go to the bathroom. But your gut does *so much more*. It’s the
control center for immunity, mood, metabolism, and even sleep. In fact, over 70% of your immune
system lives in your gut, and your microbiome is constantly communicating with your brain through
the gut-brain axis.

That means if your gut is out of balance, the ripple effects can show up everywhere: fatigue, skin
issues, brain fog, low mood, and more. Below are the top signs your gut may be asking for a
reset—and why working with a nutrition professional can help you get to the root cause instead of
just masking symptoms.

### 1. Bloating That Doesn’t Quit

A little gas after Taco Tuesday? Totally normal. But if you feel bloated after most meals (or even
after drinking water), it could signal imbalances in your microbiome, food intolerances, or sluggish
digestion. Persistent bloating may also point to conditions like small intestinal bacterial
overgrowth (SIBO) or poor enzyme activity.

Why it matters: Chronic bloating isn’t just uncomfortable—it can mean your gut isn’t properly
breaking down food or absorbing nutrients, which impacts immunity and energy.

### 2. Bathroom “Surprises”

Constipation, diarrhea, or swinging between the two is your gut waving a big red flag. Consistent,
easy bowel movements are one of the best markers of gut health. If your routine feels unpredictable,
your digestion and microbial balance may be struggling.

Why it matters: Irregular bowel patterns can cause inflammation, affect nutrient absorption, and
weaken immune defenses.

### 3. Skin Acting Up

Skin issues like acne, eczema, and rosacea often trace back to the gut. Research shows strong ties
between gut inflammation, dysbiosis (microbial imbalance), and skin conditions.

Why it matters: Your skin is an extension of your gut. When your microbiome is off, toxins and
inflammatory compounds may “leak” through the gut lining and show up on your skin.

### 4. Food Intolerance Creep

Foods you once tolerated are suddenly leaving you bloated, crampy, or foggy? That can happen when
the gut lining weakens (leaky gut) or the microbiome loses diversity.

Why it matters: Ignoring new food reactions may mean missing an underlying imbalance that, over
time, can affect nutrient status, immunity, and even hormone balance.

### 5. Low Energy and Brain Fog

If your gut isn’t digesting and absorbing nutrients well, your whole body suffers—including your
brain. Gut inflammation has been linked to fatigue, mood swings, and cognitive issues.

Why it matters: Your microbiome produces neurotransmitters like serotonin and GABA, which regulate
mood and mental clarity. When the gut is off, your brain feels it.

### 6. Frequent Sugar or Carb Cravings

Those intense sugar cravings might not be “you being weak”—they can actually come from an overgrowth
of yeast or certain bacteria that thrive on sugar.

Why it matters: Feeding these microbes can worsen imbalances, fuel inflammation, and create an
ongoing cycle of cravings and crashes.

### 7. Immune System Red Flags

If you catch every bug going around or have lingering colds, your gut might be involved. With most
of your immune cells located in the gut, microbial imbalances or inflammation can leave you more
vulnerable.

Why it matters: Gut health and immune health are inseparable. Addressing gut imbalances helps build
resilience so you’re not constantly sidelined by illness.

### 8. Bad Breath (Even With Good Oral Hygiene)

Persistent bad breath can come from deeper in the digestive tract, not just your mouth. If brushing
and flossing don’t solve it, your gut bacteria may be part of the story.

Why it matters: Oral health and gut health are connected. Unchecked microbial imbalances can affect
both.

### 9. Unexplained Aches and Inflammation

Gut imbalances can drive systemic inflammation, which sometimes shows up as joint pain, stiffness,
or body aches without a clear cause.

Why it matters: Low-grade inflammation starting in the gut doesn’t stay in the gut. Over time, it
can impact heart health, metabolic function, and even autoimmune risk.

### 10. Sleep Struggles

The gut helps regulate serotonin and melatonin, which are critical for restful sleep. If your
microbiome is struggling, your sleep may suffer.

Why it matters: Poor sleep then worsens gut health—a vicious cycle that leaves you exhausted and
inflamed.

### Simple Steps to Support Gut Health at Home

While everyone’s needs are different, here are simple, evidence-based habits that can help ease
symptoms and support your gut:

- **Take a 10-minute walk after meals** → movement improves digestion and helps regulate blood sugar.
- **Chew thoroughly and eat slowly** → this activates digestive enzymes and reduces swallowed air (a
big bloating culprit).
- **Skip the straw (and gum)** → both can increase how much air you swallow, leading to gas and
bloating.
- **Stay hydrated** → water keeps stool moving and supports your gut lining.

If you love the cozy flavors of chicken pot pie but want something easier, lighter, and completely
gluten- and dairy-free, this Chicken Pot Pie Pasta is the ultimate comfort food makeover. It’s
creamy, hearty, and nourishing — all made in one pan in about 30 minutes. This recipe uses
rotisserie chicken, vegetables, and a rich, creamy sauce made without cream or cheese. It’s the
perfect gluten-free and dairy-free comfort food for any night of the week.

### Quick Overview

- **Servings:** 4–6
- **Prep Time:** 10 minutes
- **Cook Time:** 25 minutes
- **Total Time:** 35 minutes

## Ingredients

- 2 tablespoons vegan butter
- 1 teaspoon minced garlic
- 1 medium onion, diced
- 1 (12–16 oz) bag frozen peas and carrots blend
- 2 tablespoons gluten-free flour
- 1 cup unsweetened plant-based milk (almond or oat)
- 1 cup chicken bone broth
- 1 rotisserie chicken, deboned and chopped (about 2–2½ cups)
- 2 teaspoons chicken bouillon paste (*Better Than Bouillon* or similar)
- ½ teaspoon salt (or to taste)
- ½ teaspoon black pepper
- 1 teaspoon dried parsley
- 1 teaspoon marjoram
- ½ teaspoon thyme leaves
- 1 (8–12 oz) box Banza pasta, cooked and drained

## Instructions

### 1. Sauté Onion

In a large skillet or sauté pan, melt the vegan butter over medium heat. Add the diced onion and
cook until translucent, about 4–5 minutes.

### 2. Add Garlic and Vegetables

Stir in the minced garlic and the frozen peas and carrots. Cook for 5–6 minutes, until the

Fiber: Why This Nutrient Deserves More Attention Than You Think Nutrition

If there’s one nutrient that consistently earns praise from nutrition experts and researchers alike,
it’s fiber. Yet despite its reputation as a health powerhouse, most Americans are still falling
short — averaging only about 17 grams per day when the recommended intake is 25–38 grams.

So what exactly is fiber, why does it matter so much, and what’s the deal with TikTok’s viral “fiber
maxxing” trend? Let’s unpack the facts.

## What Is Dietary Fiber?

Dietary fiber is a type of non-digestible carbohydrate found in plant foods. Unlike other carbs,
fiber passes through your digestive tract mostly intact — and that’s a good thing. It supports
everything from gut health to blood sugar control, heart health, and even longevity.

There are two main types of fiber, and both play important but different roles:

- Soluble fiber dissolves in water, forming a gel-like substance in the gut. It’s found in foods like
oats, beans, lentils, apples, pears, and flaxseed. It helps lower cholesterol, improves blood sugar
control, and supports a healthy gut microbiome.
- Insoluble fiber does not dissolve in water and helps add bulk to stool, promoting regular bowel
movements. It’s abundant in whole grains, vegetables, nuts, and seeds. It. supports digestive
regularity and reduces constipation.

## Why Fiber Matters: The Science-Backed Benefits

Decades of research show that fiber is far more than a digestive aid — it’s a cornerstone of disease
prevention.

People who consume the most fiber have been shown to have 15–30% lower risk of:

- Heart disease and stroke
- Type 2 diabetes
- Obesity
- Colorectal cancer
- All-cause and cardiovascular mortality

Fiber also promotes metabolic balance by feeding beneficial gut bacteria. These microbes produce
short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) that lower inflammation, support immune health, and help regulate
appetite and weight.

## How Much Fiber Do You Actually Need?

The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics and the American Heart Association recommend:

- Women: 25 grams per day
- Men: 38 grams per day

Unfortunately, most adults fall short by about 40–50%. That’s why a conscious effort to include
fiber-rich foods at each meal can make a significant difference!

## Good Sources of Fiber

You don’t need supplements to hit your goals — food can do the heavy lifting. Some top choices
include:

- Whole grains: oats, quinoa, brown rice, amaranth, buckwheat
- Legumes: lentils, chickpeas, black beans, split peas
- Fruits: apples, pears, raspberries, avocados
- Vegetables: broccoli, Brussels sprouts, carrots, leafy greens
- Nuts & seeds: chia, flaxseed, almonds, pistachios

*Bonus:*Aim for variety — different fibers nourish different types of gut bacteria, creating a more
resilient microbiome!

## How to Increase Fiber Intake (Without the Bloat)

Jumping from 10 grams to 35 grams overnight is a recipe for gas and discomfort. Instead, increase
fiber gradually:

1. Add one fiber-rich food per meal.
2. Drink plenty of water — fiber needs fluid to move smoothly through your system.
3. Choose whole foods over processed options.
4. Try swapping white rice for quinoa, chips for roasted chickpeas, or cereal for oatmeal.

Your gut will thank you — and within a few weeks, your digestion, energy, and satiety levels will
noticeably improve!

## Common Myths About Fiber

Myth 1: Fiber only matters for constipation. While it’s great for keeping things moving, fiber’s
benefits extend far beyond digestion. It helps regulate cholesterol, blood sugar, and inflammation —
all key to long-term health.

Myth 2: You need fiber supplements to meet your goals. Supplements can help in some cases, but most
people can easily reach their targets with real food. Whole foods offer additional nutrients and
phytochemicals that powders and pills can’t replicate.

Myth 3: More fiber is always better. More isn’t necessarily better. Going overboard — or “fiber
maxxing” — can cause bloating, gas, and even nutrient malabsorption. The goal is balance, not
excess.

## The TikTok Trend: What Is “Fiber Maxxing”?

The term “fiber maxxing” has gone viral on TikTok, with users showcasing massive bowls of high-fiber
meals claiming to boost gut health and weight loss.

While increasing fiber is beneficial, context matters:

- Rapidly ramping up fiber without enough fluids or gut adaptation can lead to discomfort ranging from
pain and bloating to constipation or diarrhea.
- Extremely high fiber intakes may reduce absorption of minerals like zinc and iron. The point is to
increase nutrients through balance, not deplete them!
- Everyone’s gut tolerance is different — what feels great for one person might cause a myriad of
issues for another.

In short, focus on sustainable, gradual increases rather than extremes. Healthy living is all about
balance and moderation!

## The Bottom Line

Fiber is one of the most powerful (and underrated) nutrients for disease prevention, digestive
health, and metabolic balance.

If you’re looking to support your gut, balance blood sugar, manage weight, and protect long-term
health, increasing your fiber intake from whole foods is a simple, evidence-based step in the right
direction.

Start small, go slow, and let your body adjust — your microbiome will do the rest!

Navigating Emotional Eating During the Holidays: A Gentle Guide to Staying Grounded

The holidays bring joy, connection, and celebration, but they also bring more stress, more food,
less sleep, more emotions, and way less structure.****So if you find yourself eating more sweets,
grazing all day, or feeling “out of control” around food, it’s not a character flaw or a lack of
discipline. It’s your nervous system doing the best it can with limited capacity and high demand.
Think of it more as biology, stress, and your environment rather than a lack of willpower.

Below is a simple, step-by-step checklist you can use anytime emotional eating pops up. Think of it
as a gentle interruption, not a rulebook, to help you reconnect with your body and your values or
goals when things feel chaotic.

## 1. Pause & Breathe

Before anything else, take a moment to slow your body down. Emotional eating often happens in
milliseconds – you feel something uncomfortable, your brain wants relief, and food becomes the
fastest fix.

A 30–120 second pause interrupts that loop.

Why it works:****Deep breathing activates your parasympathetic system, lowering cortisol and
reducing the intensity of an urge. Slowing down gives the thinking part of your brain (the
prefrontal cortex) a chance to come back online.

How to do it:

- 5 slow belly breaths
- Hand on heart + long, slow exhale
- Inhale for 4 seconds, exhale for 6 seconds

A pause doesn’t eliminate the urge; it just gives you space to choose what comes next.

## 2. The HALT Check

HALT stands for Hungry, Angry/Anxious, Lonely, Tired – the four states most linked to emotional
eating.

Why it works: Emotional eating is often a misdirected attempt to meet an emotional or physical need.
HALT helps you identify what that need actually is.

Ask yourself:

- Am I physically hungry?
- Am I angry, anxious, or stressed?
- Am I feeling lonely, disconnected, or needing comfort?
- Am I tired, overstimulated, or mentally drained?

If hunger is low, emotional needs are probably high, and food won’t fix those needs.

## 3. Name the Emotion

Once you identify the feeling, say it out loud or in your head.

Why it works: Labeling emotions reduces their intensity. This is a well-documented psychological
effect known as “affect labeling.” When you name the emotion, your brain automatically shifts from
reaction mode to regulation mode.

Examples:

- “I’m feeling overwhelmed and tapped out.”
- “I’m lonely and needing comfort.”
- “I’m stressed and overstimulated.”

Remember, you’re not judging the emotion, you’re just acknowledging it.

## 4. Create an Acceptance Moment

Instead of fighting the craving or shaming yourself, practice acceptance. This comes from ACT
(Acceptance & Commitment Therapy).

Why it works: Resistance makes urges stronger. Acceptance reduces their power.

Try saying:

- “This craving is a signal, not an emergency.”
- “I can feel this emotion without using food to numb it.”
- “My body is asking for comfort, and I can decide how to respond.”

You’re permitting yourself to feel without needing to fix.

## 5. Interoception Check-In

Interoception is your ability to sense internal cues like hunger, fullness, or emotional tension.
Observe your body’s signals: Growling stomach, low energy, lightheadedness, or irritability are
physical signs of hunger. Cravings without these signs may be emotional or boredom-driven.

Why it works: Many people confuse emotional discomfort with hunger because both come from the same
area of the body (the gut and chest).

Rate your hunger from 0–10:

- 0–4: likely emotional or boredom-driven
- 5–7: genuine hunger
- 8–10: you may have waited too long to eat

This step teaches you to interpret what your body is truly asking for.

## 6. Choose a Non-Food Coping Strategy

Once you know what you’re feeling, choose a small action that meets that need more directly than
food.

**If it’s boredom:**

Food provides stimulation (especially sugar). Replace the stimulation instead of eating to fill
time.

Try:

- Step outside for a change of environment
- Switch rooms to reset your brain
- Text a friend for a quick connection
- Do a 2-minute household task
- Engage in a valued activity: reading, stretching, cuddling your kids, folding laundry, journaling

Why it works: Boredom often comes from low dopamine and mental under-stimulation. Changing your
environment or doing a small task boosts dopamine and reduces the urge to “eat for something to do.”

**If it’s emotional overwhelm:**

Food is often used as a numbing or grounding tool. Instead, support your nervous system.

Try:

- 5-4-3-2-1 sensory grounding (name 5 things you can see, 4 things you can feel, 3 things you can
hear, 2 things you can smell, and 1 thing you can taste or your favorite taste)
- Deep breathing
- Shake out physical tension
- Hug your partner or pet
- Sit in a quiet room for 60 seconds
- Put your hands in warm water

Why it works: These strategies regulate your nervous system, helping your body shift from “fight-or-
flight” to “rest-and-digest.” When your physiology changes, the need to self-soothe with food
naturally decreases.

## 7. Practice “Urge Surfing”

Urge surfing is a mindfulness technique that teaches you to ride the wave of a craving.

How it works: Instead of reacting to the urge, you observe it like a wave – notice it rise, peak,
and fall.

Why it works: Most cravings only last 5–20 minutes if you don’t feed them with attention or
resistance. Surfing the urge teaches you that urges are temporary, not emergencies.

## 8. If You’re Actually Hungry, Eat a Balanced Snack

If your hunger rating was 5 or higher, your body needs nourishment.

Choose snacks that help stabilize:

- Apple + almond butter
- Veggies + hummus
- Roasted edamame
- Turkey roll-ups + veggies
- Dairy-free yogurt + berries + flax
- Nuts + pear or apple
- Tuna packet + whole-grain crackers

Why it works: Protein + fiber stabilizes blood sugar, which reduces future cravings and prevents the
“eat → crash → crave → repeat” cycle.

## 9. End with Self-Compassion

No matter what happens, whether you ate or didn’t, end with kindness.

Try:

- “I’m human, and this moment doesn’t define me.”
- “My body and emotions are giving me information, not shame.”
- “I’m learning skills, not aiming for perfection.”

Why it works: Self-compassion is one of the strongest predictors of reduced emotional eating long-
term. Punishment actually increases emotional eating; compassion interrupts the cycle.

especially nostalgic, tasty treats- while also navigating more stress, more emotion, less sleep, and
far less structure. Social expectations ramp up, routines disappear, and old memories or family
dynamics can stir up triggers we weren’t expecting. Add in the quiet pressure of “I should be happy
right now,” and it’s no wonder our capacity to regulate feels lower, and our urge to cope with food
feels higher.

So if you find yourself eating more sweets, grazing mindlessly, or feeling less in control than

environment that demands more than it gives back. What matters most isn’t perfection, especially not
this time of year. What matters is having a gentle way to interrupt the cycle with awareness,
compassion, and tools that support you rather than punish you.

presence throughout the season.

It’s your nervous system doing the best it can with limited capacity and high demand. Think of it more as biology, stress, and your environment rather than a lack of willpower.

Below is a simple, step-by-step checklist you can use anytime emotional eating pops up. Think of it as a gentle interruption, not a rulebook, to help you reconnect with your body and your values or goals when things feel chaotic.

1. Pause & Breathe

Before anything else, take a moment to slow your body down. Emotional eating often happens in milliseconds – you feel something uncomfortable, your brain wants relief, and food becomes the fastest fix.

A 30–120 second pause interrupts that loop.

Why it works:****Deep breathing activates your parasympathetic system, lowering cortisol and reducing the intensity of an urge. Slowing down gives the thinking part of your brain (the prefrontal cortex) a chance to come back online.

How to do it:

  • 5 slow belly breaths
  • Hand on heart + long, slow exhale
  • Inhale for 4 seconds, exhale for 6 seconds

A pause doesn’t eliminate the urge; it just gives you space to choose what comes next.

2. The HALT Check

HALT stands for Hungry, Angry/Anxious, Lonely, Tired – the four states most linked to emotional eating.

Why it works: Emotional eating is often a misdirected attempt to meet an emotional or physical need. HALT helps you identify what that need actually is.

Ask yourself:

  • Am I physically hungry?
  • Am I angry, anxious, or stressed?
  • Am I feeling lonely, disconnected, or needing comfort?
  • Am I tired, overstimulated, or mentally drained?

If hunger is low, emotional needs are probably high, and food won’t fix those needs.

3. Name the Emotion

Once you identify the feeling, say it out loud or in your head.

Why it works: Labeling emotions reduces their intensity. This is a well-documented psychological effect known as “affect labeling.” When you name the emotion, your brain automatically shifts from reaction mode to regulation mode.

Examples:

  • “I’m feeling overwhelmed and tapped out.”
  • “I’m lonely and needing comfort.”
  • “I’m stressed and overstimulated.”

Remember, you’re not judging the emotion, you’re just acknowledging it.

4. Create an Acceptance Moment

Instead of fighting the craving or shaming yourself, practice acceptance. This comes from ACT (Acceptance & Commitment Therapy).

Why it works: Resistance makes urges stronger. Acceptance reduces their power.

Try saying:

  • “This craving is a signal, not an emergency.”
  • “I can feel this emotion without using food to numb it.”
  • “My body is asking for comfort, and I can decide how to respond.”

You’re permitting yourself to feel without needing to fix.

5. Interoception Check-In

Interoception is your ability to sense internal cues like hunger, fullness, or emotional tension. Observe your body’s signals: Growling stomach, low energy, lightheadedness, or irritability are physical signs of hunger. Cravings without these signs may be emotional or boredom-driven.

Why it works: Many people confuse emotional discomfort with hunger because both come from the same area of the body (the gut and chest).

Rate your hunger from 0–10:

  • 0–4: likely emotional or boredom-driven
  • 5–7: genuine hunger
  • 8–10: you may have waited too long to eat

This step teaches you to interpret what your body is truly asking for.

6. Choose a Non-Food Coping Strategy

Once you know what you’re feeling, choose a small action that meets that need more directly than food.

If it’s boredom:

Food provides stimulation (especially sugar). Replace the stimulation instead of eating to fill time.

Try:

  • Step outside for a change of environment
  • Switch rooms to reset your brain
  • Text a friend for a quick connection
  • Do a 2-minute household task
  • Engage in a valued activity: reading, stretching, cuddling your kids, folding laundry, journaling

Why it works: Boredom often comes from low dopamine and mental under-stimulation. Changing your environment or doing a small task boosts dopamine and reduces the urge to “eat for something to do.”

If it’s emotional overwhelm:

Food is often used as a numbing or grounding tool. Instead, support your nervous system.

Try:

  • 5-4-3-2-1 sensory grounding (name 5 things you can see, 4 things you can feel, 3 things you can hear, 2 things you can smell, and 1 thing you can taste or your favorite taste)
  • Deep breathing
  • Shake out physical tension
  • Hug your partner or pet
  • Sit in a quiet room for 60 seconds
  • Put your hands in warm water

Why it works: These strategies regulate your nervous system, helping your body shift from “fight-or- flight” to “rest-and-digest.” When your physiology changes, the need to self-soothe with food naturally decreases.

7. Practice “Urge Surfing”

Urge surfing is a mindfulness technique that teaches you to ride the wave of a craving.

How it works: Instead of reacting to the urge, you observe it like a wave – notice it rise, peak, and fall.

Why it works: Most cravings only last 5–20 minutes if you don’t feed them with attention or resistance. Surfing the urge teaches you that urges are temporary, not emergencies.

8. If You’re Actually Hungry, Eat a Balanced Snack

If your hunger rating was 5 or higher, your body needs nourishment.

Choose snacks that help stabilize:

  • Apple + almond butter
  • Veggies + hummus
  • Roasted edamame
  • Turkey roll-ups + veggies
  • Dairy-free yogurt + berries + flax
  • Nuts + pear or apple
  • Tuna packet + whole-grain crackers

Why it works: Protein + fiber stabilizes blood sugar, which reduces future cravings and prevents the “eat → crash → crave → repeat” cycle.

9. End with Self-Compassion

No matter what happens, whether you ate or didn’t, end with kindness.

Try:

  • “I’m human, and this moment doesn’t define me.”
  • “My body and emotions are giving me information, not shame.”
  • “I’m learning skills, not aiming for perfection.”

Why it works: Self-compassion is one of the strongest predictors of reduced emotional eating long- term. Punishment actually increases emotional eating; compassion interrupts the cycle.

Why This Matters So Much During the Holidays

The holiday season creates the perfect storm for emotional eating. We’re surrounded by more food, especially nostalgic, tasty treats- while also navigating more stress, more emotion, less sleep, and far less structure. Social expectations ramp up, routines disappear, and old memories or family dynamics can stir up triggers we weren’t expecting. Add in the quiet pressure of “I should be happy right now,” and it’s no wonder our capacity to regulate feels lower, and our urge to cope with food feels higher.

So if you find yourself eating more sweets, grazing mindlessly, or feeling less in control than usual, it’s not a sign of weakness. It’s a sign that your nervous system is overwhelmed by an environment that demands more than it gives back. What matters most isn’t perfection, especially not this time of year. What matters is having a gentle way to interrupt the cycle with awareness, compassion, and tools that support you rather than punish you.

Give yourself permission to be human this season—messy, emotional, joyful, tired, imperfect, and still completely worthy of care! Wishing you moments of calm, joyful nourishment, and mindful presence throughout the season.

The Non-Negotiables of Wellness: Four Foundations Every Body Needs

When it comes to health, there’s no universal plan that fits everyone. Personalized nutrition and
lifestyle choices are essential, but certain habits support nearly all aspects of well-being — no
matter who you are. These daily habits create the foundation that allows your body’s personalized
plan to actually *work.*

From a clinical and practical standpoint, these are the non-negotiables I encourage every client to
prioritize: daylight and time outdoors, daily movement, balanced nutrient-dense meals, and
restorative sleep. They may sound simple, but each is deeply supported by research and critical for
metabolic, hormonal, and emotional health.

## Daylight and Time Outdoors: Regulate, Reset, and Recharge

Exposure to natural light helps regulate your circadian rhythm, the internal clock that influences
sleep, metabolism, and mood. Morning and daytime light exposure improves alertness, energy, and
focus while enhancing sleep quality later in the evening.

Research shows that insufficient sunlight exposure is linked to a higher risk of cardiovascular
disease, metabolic syndrome, and certain cancers. These benefits go beyond vitamin D — sunlight also
supports healthy blood pressure and immune regulation. On the other hand, avoiding bright light at
night helps maintain melatonin production and a healthy sleep-wake cycle.

Practical tip: Get outside within an hour of waking, even for 10–15 minutes. Morning daylight cues
your body to be alert and sets the tone for better rest at night!

## Movement: Support Strength, Energy, and Longevity

Movement is one of the strongest predictors of long-term health. Regular physical activity lowers
the risk of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and cancer while improving mood, focus, and sleep
quality. Even small increases in activity — such as a short walk after meals or taking the stairs —
can have measurable health benefits.

Exercise also supports circadian alignment and metabolic efficiency, helping your body maintain
consistent rhythms that regulate hormones and blood sugar.

Practical tip: Choose a type of movement you enjoy and can sustain daily — walking, running,
stretching, strength training, dancing, hiking, or swimming. And remember, consistency matters more
than intensity!

## Eating Regular, Balanced Meals: Nourish and Stabilize

What and when we eat both influence how we feel and function. Research shows that irregular eating
patterns are associated with a higher risk of metabolic syndrome and adverse lipid profiles. In
contrast, eating at consistent times throughout the day improves insulin sensitivity, energy
regulation, and weight management.

Balanced meals built from nutrient-dense, whole foods provide the macro- and micronutrients your
body needs to thrive. They also support steady energy, mood stability, and digestion. Read more
about building balanced meals [HERE](../how-to-build-balanced-meals-for-health.html).

Practical tip: Aim to eat every four to five hours, combining protein, fiber-rich carbohydrates, and
healthy fats. Regular nourishment signals safety to your body and promotes stable metabolism
throughout the day!

## Sleep: The Foundation of Recovery and Regulation

Sleep is when your body restores itself. Consistent sleep timing and adequate duration (typically
seven to nine hours per night) are essential for cardiometabolic, cognitive, and emotional health.

Poor or irregular sleep increases the risk of diabetes, hypertension, and emotional dysregulation.
In fact, research shows that sleep *regularity* is just as important as duration for maintaining
healthy circadian rhythms.

Practical tip: Protect your sleep routine as you would any important appointment. Limit screens
before bed, keep your room dark and cool, and aim for a consistent bedtime and wake time each day!

## The Bottom Line

True wellness is personal, but the foundations are universal. Regular daylight, daily movement,
nourishing food, and quality sleep form the non-negotiable core of a well-functioning body and mind.

Start small and stay consistent – your body thrives on rhythm, nourishment, and rest. Think of these
things as the recipe for success. Once these are in place, personalized nutrition and lifestyle
strategies become far more effective — because you’ve already built a strong foundation for your
body to thrive!

How to Build Balanced Meals for Health

If you’ve ever stared at your plate and thought, *“Is this balanced? I am getting what I need?”*,
you’re not alone. The truth is, building **balanced meals** doesn’t require a nutrition degree,
fancy apps, or measuring every gram. With the **balanced plate method**, you can fill your plate (or
bowl) with the nutrients your body actually needs: protein, non-starchy vegetables, whole grains or
fruit, and healthy fats. This is often one of the first lessons I will have with my clients when we
begin a new care plan. It’s all about balance!

Think of it as painting your meal with all the right colors—no perfection required, just nutrients
that make you feel good!

### Why Balanced Meals Matter

Balanced meals provide steady energy, satisfy your hunger, and provide essential nutrients without
the stress of counting calories (which BTW we don’t do around here!). Using the **plate method**
ensures your body gets:

- Enough **protein** to support muscles and metabolism – yay!
- Plenty of **non-starchy vegetables** for fiber, vitamins, and minerals
- Smart **carbs from whole grains or fruit** to fuel your busy days
- **Healthy fats** to keep hormones, brain, and digestion happy

### Step 1: ¼ Plate = Protein

Protein anchors your plate. It keeps you satisfied, supports your metabolism, and helps maintain
muscle mass.

#### Protein Ideas:

- Chicken, turkey, lean beef, pork tenderloin
- Tofu, tempeh, lentils, beans
- Eggs or egg substitutes
- Dairy-free Greek-style yogurt
- Protein powder for smoothies or bowls

**Pro tip:** A palm-sized portion is perfect—no scale needed.

### Step 2: ½ Plate = Non-Starchy Vegetables

Non-starchy vegetables are your meal’s fiber-packed superheroes. They add vitamins, minerals,
antioxidants, and bulk—without spiking blood sugar.

#### Non-Starchy Veggie Picks:

- Leafy greens: spinach, kale, arugula
- Cruciferous veggies: broccoli, cauliflower, Brussels sprouts
- Others: peppers, zucchini, cucumbers, carrots

### Step 3: ¼ Plate = Whole Grains, Starchy Veggies, or Fruit

Carbs get a bad rap, but when you choose the right ones, they fuel your body and provide fiber,
vitamins, and minerals.

#### Smart Carb Options:

- **Whole grains:** quinoa, brown rice, oats
- **Starchy veggies:** sweet potatoes, winter squash, peas, corn, all other potatoes
- **Fruit:** berries, apples, pears, oranges, grapes

### Step 4: Add 1–2 Tablespoons of Healthy Fats

Healthy fats are the flavor, texture, and nutrient boosters that make meals enjoyable and
satisfying. They also help your body to absorb fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K).

#### Healthy Fat Options:

- Avocado (bonus: fiber + fat = dream team)
- Nuts and seeds: almonds, walnuts, chia, flax, pumpkin seeds
- Olive oil, avocado oil, sesame oil
- A flavorful dressing with one of the above oils

### The Plate Method in Action

Here’s what a balanced plate looks like:

- **¼ plate:** grilled chicken (protein)
- **½ plate:** roasted broccoli, carrots, and zucchini (non-starchy veg)
- **¼ plate:** quinoa or a baked sweet potato (whole grain/starchy carb)
- **1Tbsp fat:** avocado slices or a sprinkle of seeds (healthy fat + fiber)

Seasonal Allergy Relief: Diet, Lifestyle, and Natural Support

Fall is a beautiful season, but for many people, it also brings sneezing, itchy eyes, congestion,
and fatigue. These symptoms are often due to seasonal allergies, also known as hay fever or allergic
rhinitis. While medications can help, diet, lifestyle, and select supplements complement traditional
medications and may reduce the intensity of symptoms and improve overall quality of life.

This guide will help you understand what seasonal allergies are, their common symptoms, and how
nutrition and natural strategies can support your body during allergy season.

## What Are Seasonal Allergies?

Seasonal allergies are an immune response to environmental triggers like pollen, mold spores, and
grasses. When your body perceives these particles as harmful, it releases histamine from MAST cells,
causing sneezing, congestion, watery eyes, and itching, among other common symptoms.

Although common allergens vary by location, typical allergy seasons include:

- Spring (March–April): Tree pollen
- Summer (June–July): Grass pollen
- Fall (August–October): Ragweed and mold spores

Some people react only in one season, while others struggle year-round due to multiple triggers.

## Signs and Symptoms of Seasonal Allergies

If you’re sensitive to seasonal allergens, you may experience:

- Runny or itchy nose
- Sneezing
- Watery or swollen eyes
- Hives, rashes, or itchy skin
- Nasal congestion and post-nasal drip
- Coughing or sore throat
- Headaches and fatigue

## Why Do Seasonal Allergies Happen?

The histamine response is central to allergy symptoms. Histamine, released from mast cells and
basophils, triggers inflammation, swelling, and mucus production.

Some individuals have a harder time clearing histamine, leading to symptom “overload.” This can be
influenced by:

- Genetics
- Liver detoxification capacity
- Gut microbiome diversity

Emerging evidence shows that people with allergic rhinitis often have **reduced gut microbial
diversity**. This ties into the hygiene hypothesis: reduced exposure to microbes (due to less
farming, fewer siblings, more antibiotics, sterile living) may leave the immune system unbalanced
and more prone to allergies.

## Lifestyle Foundations for Allergy Relief

Even before diet changes, these lifestyle habits can reduce allergen exposure:

- Check pollen counts and avoid outdoor activities during peak times.
- Keep windows closed and use HEPA filters indoors.
- Wash bedding weekly in hot water.
- Shower and change clothes after being outdoors
- Rinse nasal passages with saline to clear allergens from airways.

## Therapeutic Diet for Seasonal Allergies

Food is one of the most powerful tools for reducing inflammation and histamine overload. Focusing on
foods that are both anti-inflammatory and low-histamine can be the key to reducing inflammation,
maintaining a healthy microbiome, and lowering histamine overload.

If you’ve ever felt overwhelmed by the overabundance of conflicting health and wellness advice out there—one day a food is “super,” and the next it’s “toxic” and to be avoided at all costs (insert eyeroll here!)—you’re not alone. My goal with this blog is to help you cut through the noise and get back to the basics: evidence-based, trustworthy nutrition information that actually makes sense for real life.

But before we dive in, let me share a little about myself. I’m Jen, a board-certified nutrition professional who is passionate about helping people feel their best and live more life through practical, evidence-based strategies. When I’m not working with clients or digging into research, you’ll usually find me surrounded by my collection of houseplants, hanging out with my three dachshunds, or enjoying a really good meal (because yes—I love food too!).

This blog is not about perfection. The photos won’t always be polished, the recipes won’t always look “Pinterest-ready,” and I don’t pretend to be a blogging or social media expert. What I do promise is to show up as a real person who cares deeply about your health and to focus on sharing high-quality, evidence-based information you can trust.

Here, you’ll find conversations and resources on topics like:

  • Eating for optimal health and wellness
  • Simple, delicious recipes you’ll actually want to make
  • Healthy aging and supporting long-term vitality
  • Practical guidance for managing common conditions
  • Tips for living well without unnecessary stress or restriction

Think of this space as us sitting down together at the table, sorting through what’s real, what’s hype, and what can help you live a healthier, happier life—without the pressure of perfection.

I can’t wait to share ideas, answer your questions, and connect with you along the way. So grab a cup of coffee (or tea), maybe a dog (or other furry creature you adore) to curl up with, and let’s start this journey together!

Make sure you check out How to Build Balanced Meals for Health. This will provide you with a solid foundation for understanding how to assemble meals that truly nourish your body and support your health goals. Think of it as our starting point—the basics we’ll keep building on as we explore more topics together!
